Award.AbstractNarration: Plant xylem, or wood, is the most abundant tissue on land. Of all vascular tissues, it carries the most fluid - water - the longest distances. How it functions influences everything from photosynthesis and soil respiration to the weather. This research focuses on two key properties of wood function: sustaining negative water pressure without cavitating to the vapor phase, and maintaining minimal frictional resistance to flow. These properties influence plant stress tolerance and productivity. Cavitation is caused by failure of valve-like "pits" between conduits. The research will test the probability-based hypothesis that the vulnerability to cavitation increases as the number of pits per conduit increases. Tests will involve air-injection experiments and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) to view vasculature inside intact trees. "Natural experiments" will compare flowering plants with the more ancient plant group, Gnetophytes, separate lineages with distinct pit structure. The research will also evaluate the contribution of perforation plates, the joints between conduit elements, to flow resistance. These joints have evolved from high-resistance, pitted end-walls, to openings as wide as the conduit. The functional properties of this morphological gradient will be documented in parallel lineages of flowering plants and Gnetophytes. Single-conduit measurements and finite-element modeling will link joint structure to flow resistance. Results of this research will fill the sizable gap between our knowledge of wood structure and the performance of plants in their natural and cultivated environments. Among the broader impacts of this research will be the development of image-analysis software for rapid inference of functional properties from microscopic images of wood. This "structure-function" index will be freely available to educators and researchers. It will be essential for extracting functional data from extensive collections of wood, including fossils, held in institutions around the world. The project will also involve training of undergraduate and graduate students as well as post-doctoral associates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Vascular functioning in plants is as central to their health and performance as vascular functioning in humans. The research focused on the water-conducting vascular tissue, the xylem. Xylem transports more fluid over longer distances than any other vascular system. The remarkable cohesion-tension mechanism pulls water from the soil, against gravity and friction, to the leaves where it evaporates through open stomatal micro-pores to the atmosphere. Stomatal water loss is the physically inevitable consequence of stomatal CO2 uptake.  Xylem transport capacity hypothetically limits CO2 uptake and plant growth by limiting the opening of the stomatal valves. Because the xylem water is pulled up the plant, it is under negative liquid pressure. The water pressure is so negative that it extends well into the metastable realm where even microscopic gas bubbles can trigger the phase-change to vapor and disrupt transport by creating a gas embolism in the xylem conduits. A major consequence of drought stress in plants is the development of cavitation and embolism which disrupts the plant water supply.          

The research resulted in 34 scientific publications that advanced our knowledge of xylem functioning in plants. Several papers found strong evidence to support the hypothetical link between xylem transport capacity and plant metabolic rate. The research confirmed the proposed 1:1 scaling between xylem transport capacity, plant water consumption, and plant growth rates in a variety of diverse woody plants. A relatively simple model successfully predicted plant water use and its increase with plant size as a function of xylem anatomical parameters and branching patterns. The model was applied across diverse tree types from evergreen conifers, to temperate and tropical hardwoods, and revealed a surprising convergence in water consumption despite divergent vascular structure. The results generally supported the vascular-based "metablic scaling theory" while also attributing deviation from theory to specific patterns of vascular and branch architecture.  

At the core of the research was the investigation of the cavitation phenomenon which disrupts xylem transport during environmental stress. Several papers addressed the validity of a centrifugal force method for measuring a plant's resistance to cavitation. In this method, stems or roots are spun in special centrifuge rotors, which puts the xylem water under negative liquid pressure (as in the functioning plant). In this way, a "vulnerability curve" can be generated showing the progressive loss of xylem transport as pressures become more negative. The research confirmed the validity of the technique in a diversity of species, suggesting that artifacts reported by other studies arose from differences in rotor design and protocol rather than a fundamental limitation of the technique. A substantial part of the research focused on the mechanism of cavitation, and its linkage to xylem structure. Cavitation is known to arise when microscopic air bubbles leak into the xylem pipes through porous "pits" in their walls. The research found strong support for the "rare pit hypothesis" which predicts that vulnerability to cavitation increases by chance with the number of pits present. Thus, larger xylem pipes (that are more efficient in transport) tend to be more vulnerable to cavitation than smaller ones because they tend to have more pits. This explains a long observed "safety vs. efficiency" trade-off in xylem structure. However, our research also found that the details of pit structure are important in determining cavitation resistance. In summary, the conclusion of the research is that cavitation resistance depends on the quantity and quality of pits present in the piping of the xylem network.
